Transform Exposure Variables in a MultiAssayExperiment

Source: R/transform_exposure.R
transform_exposure.Rd

Applies various transformation methods to numeric exposure variables in the colData of a MultiAssayExperiment object to improve normality.

Usage

transform_exposure(expomicset, exposure_cols = NULL, transform_method = "best")

Arguments

expomicset

A MultiAssayExperiment object.

exposure_cols

A character vector of column names from colData(expomicset) to transform. If NULL, the function will attempt to use metadata from check_normality().

transform_method

One of "none", "log2", "x_1_3", "sqrt", "boxcox_best", or "best" (default). "best" evaluates all available methods and chooses the one that most improves normality.

Value

A MultiAssayExperiment object with updated colData and transformation results saved in metadata(expomicset)$transformation.

Details

Supported transformations include:

  • "none": No transformation

  • "log2": Log base 2 with minimum value shift

  • "x_1_3": Cube root with minimum value shift

  • "sqrt": Square root with minimum value shift

  • "boxcox_best": Box-Cox power transformation based on optimal lambda

  • "best": Automatically selects the transformation method that best normalizes the data (based on Shapiro-Wilk test)

The "boxcox_best" transformation is based on the Box-Cox method from the MASS package. Variables are shifted to ensure strictly positive values before transformation. Lambda intervals are interpreted as follows:

  • \(\lambda < -1.5\): \(1 / x^2\)

  • \(-1.5 \leq \lambda < -0.75\): \(1 / x\)

  • \(-0.75 \leq \lambda < -0.25\): \(1 / sqrt(x)\)

  • \(-0.25 \leq \lambda < 0.25\): \(log(x)\)

  • \(0.25 \leq \lambda < 0.75\): \(sqrt(x)\)

  • \(0.75 \leq \lambda < 1.5\): identity

  • \(\lambda \geq 1.5\): \(x^2\)

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
transformed_mae <- transform_exposure(my_mae,
                                      exposure_cols = c("pm25", "no2"),
                                      transform_method = "best")
} # }
